supporting.text: Pancreas removal (pancreatectomy) is a major surgery with high medical costs, including hospitalization, surgeon fees, and post-operative care, which can lead to significant financial strain.

attacks.text: Pancreas removal (pancreatectomy) is a major surgery with high medical costs, including hospitalization, surgeon fees, and post-operative care, which can lead to significant financial strain.
Many health insurance plans cover major surgeries like pancreatectomy, reducing or eliminating out-of-pocket costs for patients.
High-deductible health plans or lack of insurance can still leave patients with substantial medical bills despite coverage.
Financial assistance programs and hospital charity care can help mitigate the costs of major surgeries for low-income patients.
Not all patients qualify for financial assistance, and charity care may not cover all expenses, leaving some with unmanageable debt.
The risk of bankruptcy depends on individual financial situations, not just medical costs; many patients manage without bankruptcy.

supporting.text: Patients who undergo pancreas removal often require lifelong insulin therapy and enzyme replacements, adding substantial ongoing medical expenses that can contribute to financial hardship.

attacks.text: Patients who undergo pancreas removal often require lifelong insulin therapy and enzyme replacements, adding substantial ongoing medical expenses that can contribute to financial hardship.
Many health insurance plans cover the majority of the costs for insulin therapy and enzyme replacements, significantly reducing the financial burden on patients.
Even with insurance, high deductibles, copays, and coverage gaps can still leave patients with substantial out-of-pocket expenses for lifelong treatments.
Not all patients who undergo pancreas removal require lifelong insulin therapy; some may retain partial pancreatic function or achieve glycemic control through other means.
The majority of pancreas removal patients do require lifelong insulin due to the loss of insulin-producing beta cells, making this the typical outcome.
Financial hardship does not necessarily equate to bankruptcy, as many patients manage these expenses through budgeting, assistance programs, or alternative income sources.
Studies show that high medical expenses are a leading cause of bankruptcy, particularly for chronic conditions requiring lifelong treatment.

supporting.text: Many countries have universal healthcare systems or insurance policies that cover major surgeries like pancreatectomy, reducing the risk of bankruptcy for patients.

attacks.text: Many countries have universal healthcare systems or insurance policies that cover major surgeries like pancreatectomy, reducing the risk of bankruptcy for patients.
Even with universal healthcare, patients may face significant out-of-pocket costs for medications, follow-up care, and lost wages due to recovery time.
Some countries with universal healthcare also provide disability benefits or income support during medical recovery, mitigating lost wages.
In countries without universal healthcare, like the US, pancreatectomy and related care can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, leading to bankruptcy.
Even in the US, many patients have employer-sponsored or ACA insurance that caps out-of-pocket costs, preventing extreme financial hardship.

supporting.text: Lost income due to extended recovery time and inability to work after pancreas removal can exacerbate financial difficulties, potentially leading to bankruptcy.

attacks.text: Lost income due to extended recovery time and inability to work after pancreas removal can exacerbate financial difficulties, potentially leading to bankruptcy.
Many patients have disability insurance or savings to cover lost income during recovery, mitigating the risk of bankruptcy.
Government or employer-provided medical leave programs often cover a significant portion of lost wages, reducing financial strain.
Pancreas removal is relatively rare, and most patients are financially prepared for major surgeries due to prior medical planning.
Disability insurance often has waiting periods and may not cover the full income, leaving gaps in financial support.
Not all employers offer paid medical leave, and government programs may have eligibility restrictions or insufficient coverage.

supporting.text: Medical bankruptcy is rare in developed nations with robust social safety nets, making it unlikely that pancreas removal alone would cause bankruptcy.

attacks.text: Medical bankruptcy is rare in developed nations with robust social safety nets, making it unlikely that pancreas removal alone would cause bankruptcy.
Even in developed nations, out-of-pocket medical expenses for chronic conditions like diabetes (post-pancreatectomy) can accumulate and lead to financial strain.
Many developed nations cap out-of-pocket costs for essential treatments, reducing the risk of catastrophic expenses from pancreas-related care.
Social safety nets often exclude indirect costs like lost wages during recovery, which can be substantial after major surgeries like pancreatectomy.
Disability benefits and sick pay policies in developed nations typically cover prolonged recovery periods, mitigating income loss.

supporting.text: Complications from pancreas removal, such as infections or diabetes management issues, can result in additional unplanned medical costs, increasing financial vulnerability.

attacks.text: Complications from pancreas removal, such as infections or diabetes management issues, can result in additional unplanned medical costs, increasing financial vulnerability.
Many health insurance plans cover complications from surgeries, reducing out-of-pocket costs for patients.
High-deductible health plans or lack of insurance can leave patients exposed to significant medical bills despite coverage for complications.
Complications like infections are rare in modern surgical practices due to advanced techniques and post-operative care.
Even with advanced techniques, individual patient factors (e.g., pre-existing conditions) can increase complication risks.
